title: Bul-bul-tara and a pick Bul-bul-tara
content:
accession_no_csv: 2016-00158

  Image: 

  object_work_type: stringed instruments (musical instruments) plectra

  title_text: Bul-bul-tara and a pick Bul-bul-tara

  preference: main alternate

  title_language: 

  creation_date: 1940-1980

  inscriptions: 

  inscription_language:

  techniques_name: forming (physical activity) woodcarving painting (image-making)

  object_colour: multicoloured

  physical_appearance: The image shows a musical instrument and pick. The pick is red in colour and it is triangle in shape. A signature can be seen on one side of the pick. The body of the instrument looks worn out as the paintwork is chipped at some areas. Two strings can be seen along the neck of the bul-bul-tara
 from the bridge to the tuning pegs. A drawing of mountains can be discerned at the middle of the bul-bul-tara. There are numerous keys on on the instrument
 and they are white at the top and brown at the bottom.

  subject_terms_1: music (performing arts) cultural artifacts

  subject_terms_2: Bulbultarang Plectra (Music) Carnatic music Musical instruments

  subject_terms_3: Instrumental music Indian music

  sgcool_label_text: Mr. Retnam (b. 1918) was a prominent musician and a bul-bul-tara (Indian Banjo or Nagoya Harp) player. Born in Penang in 1918
 he arrived in Singapore in 1929 and pursued his interest in Indian music. He popularized the use of the bul-bul-tara in Indian classical music in Singapore. Mr Retnam formed the Rama Bhajana Mandali at Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple
 and performed alongside veterans of Indian music such as Pandit M Ramalingam and MV Gurusamy. He was also a member of the Ramakrishna Sangeetha Sabha
 and Singapore Carnatic Orchestra until 1984.

metadata.physical_appearance: The image shows a musical instrument and pick. The pick is red in colour and it is triangle in shape. A signature can be seen on one side of the pick. The body of the instrument looks worn out as the paintwork is chipped at some areas. Two strings can be seen along the neck of the bul-bul-tara, from the bridge to the tuning pegs. A drawing of mountains can be discerned at the middle of the bul-bul-tara. There are numerous keys on on the instrument, and they are white at the top and brown at the bottom.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Bulbultarang Plectra (Music) Carnatic music Musical instruments
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Mr. Retnam (b. 1918) was a prominent musician and a bul-bul-tara (Indian Banjo or Nagoya Harp) player. Born in Penang in 1918, he arrived in Singapore in 1929 and pursued his interest in Indian music. He popularized the use of the bul-bul-tara in Indian classical music in Singapore. Mr Retnam formed the Rama Bhajana Mandali at Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple, and performed alongside veterans of Indian music such as Pandit M Ramalingam and MV Gurusamy. He was also a member of the Ramakrishna Sangeetha Sabha, and Singapore Carnatic Orchestra until 1984.
